706663f-a.text:
Schermerhorn Street, south side, between Flatbush and Third Avenues, showing the building of the Young Women's Christian Associatior, the view being across Temple Square. The building was later put up for sale
by the Charles F. Noyes Company.
About 1925
L. Sperr
706663f-a.folder: Schermerhorn Street & Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY

704349f-c.text:
Flatbush A enue Extension, east side, from Lafayette Street(left) to Debevoise Place, showing several old rookeries and gasolie stations. On the extreme right is a portion of the Paramount Theatre Building; the 4-story house on the left
is on Safayette Street and Debevoise Place.
April 7, 1932
P. L. Sperr
(2)
The same location, at a later date. The two upper stories of the 2appa Brothers gas station were removed; the other rookeries remaining intact, except for the change of
tenants.
April 27, 1940
P. L. Sperr
(3)
The same block, viewing from Debevoise Place to Lafayette Street. Debevoise Place is on the extreme rig ht rnd forms a forty-five degree angle with Flatbush Avenue. Beyond the Paramount Bowling Center is the four-story tenement seen on the left in view 1. Shown,too,is the factory of the Edison Screw Machine Products Company, also known as the Maltz Building.
April 27, 1940
P. L. Sperr
Ng ' 21

P. L. Sperr  August :3, 1939
